overview: Importing vehicles into the UK - registering an imported vehicle, Mutual Recognition scheme, type approval, VAT, duty and tax and moving vehicles between Great Britain and Northern Ireland
title: Importing vehicles into the UK

table.body:
^Your vehicle must obey the [Road Vehicle (Construction and Use) Regulations 1986 (as amended)](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1986/1078/contents/made "Road Vehicle (Construction and Use) Regulations 1986 (as amended)"){:rel="external"} if you use it on the road.^

If you're **permanently** importing a vehicle into the UK, you must:

- apply for [‘Mutual Recognition’ or get type approval](mutual-recognition-and-type-approval "Mutual Recognition and type approval")
- pay any [VAT, duty or tax](vat-duty-and-tax-vehicles-from-within-the-eu "VAT, duty and tax: vehicles from within the EU") due
- insure it with a [motor insurer authorised in the UK](http://www.biba.org.uk/ConsumerHome.aspx "British Insurance Brokers' Association (BIBA)"){:rel="external"}
- [register it](registering-an-imported-vehicle "Registering an imported vehicle")

Until you’ve done this, you can’t keep or use the vehicle on public roads, except to drive it to pre-arranged appointments that are necessary to register it.

There are different rules if you're [temporarily importing a vehicle into the UK](temporary-imports "Temporary imports").

^The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) advises you to transport your vehicle from the port, rather than driving it.^

##Driving with a foreign registration number

UK residents aren't allowed to use non-UK registered vehicles on UK roads. The only exceptions are if you:

- work in another European Union (EU) member state and use an EU-registered company car temporarily in the UK
- lease an EU-registered car and use this temporarily in the UK

##Vehicles over 10 years old

If you're importing a vehicle into the UK that's over 10 years old, [contact DVLA](http://www.dft.gov.uk/dvla/contactus/localoffices/findnear.aspx "Contact DVLA"){:rel="external"} to discuss registration. 

*[EU]: European Union
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You need to get a certificate of Mutual Recognition or type approval, depending on the type of vehicle and whether it was first registered within or outside the [European Union (EU).](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "Countries in the EU: Europa"){:rel="external"}

## Mutual Recognition scheme
You must apply for the Mutual Recognition scheme if you’re importing a left-hand-drive car, motorcycle or light goods vehicle first registered **within the EU**.

^To find out if your vehicle qualifies for the Mutual Recognition scheme, contact the Vehicle Certification Agency (VCA) legislation team on 0117 952 4191.^

The Mutual Recognition scheme (also known as the Commission Notice Procedure) asks you to:

- make declarations about your vehicle’s suitability for use in Britain (eg the headlight beam dips to the left)
- make alterations if needed (eg fit rear seat belts) - and provide garage receipts to prove you’ve done this

If your application is accepted, the VCA will give you a certificate. You need to present this to the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) to support your application for registration.

You can download an application form, including guidance notes, below.

$D
[Download 'CARS - Application for Commission Notice / Mutual Recognition' (PDF, 483KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_071776.pdf "Download 'CARS - Application for Commission Notice / Mutual Recognition' (PDF, 483K)"){:rel="external"}
[Download 'MOTORCYCLES - Application for Commission Notice / Mutual Recognition' (PDF, 443KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_071777.pdf "Download 'MOTORCYCLES - Application for Commission Notice / Mutual Recognition' (PDF, 443KB)"){:rel="external"}
[Download 'GOODS VEHICLES - Application for British national type approval goods vehicles under 1 year old' (PDF, 1.6MB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_071778.pdf "Download 'GOODS VEHICLES - Application for British national type approval goods vehicles under 1 year old' (PDF, 1.6MB)"){:rel="external"}
[Download 'GOODS VEHICLES 2 – Application for British national type approval goods vehicles over 1 year old' (PDF, 587KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_071779.pdf "Download 'GOODS VEHICLES 2 – Application for British national type approval goods vehicles over 1 year old' (PDF, 587KB)"){:rel="external"}
[Download 'Commission Notice plating particulars' (PDF, 93KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_196853.pdf "Download 'Commission Notice plating particulars' (PDF, 93KB)"){:rel="external"}
 $D

## European type approval

You’ll need full European [type approval](/vehicle-type-approval "Vehicle type approval") if you’re importing:

- a car, motorcycle or light goods vehicle first registered **outside the EU**
- a larger goods vehicle
- any vehicle that doesn’t have proof of European type approval (eg a certificate of conformity)

If your vehicle gets type approval, you’ll be able to register it and it will be given a [‘Q’ prefix](/vehicle-registration/q-registration-numbers " Q registration numbers") or age-related registration number.

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[VCA]: Vehicle Certification Agency
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[EU]: European Union
table.title: Mutual Recognition and type approval

table.body:
To bring any type of vehicle into Great Britain from inside the [European Union (EU),](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "Countries in the EU: Europa"){:rel="external"} you must usually:

- pay VAT, duty and/or vehicle tax
- tell HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)

You do this by filling in certain forms depending on whether your vehicle is a New Means of Transport. 

$E
Your vehicle is a **'New Means of Transport'** if either:

- it's less than 6 months old
- it has travelled fewer than 6,000 kilometres (3,750 miles) under its own power
$E

## Paying VAT
You don’t have to pay VAT if:

- you're importing a second-hand vehicle and you paid VAT in another [EU country](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "Countries in the EU: Europa"){:rel="external"}  when you bought it
- you normally live in another EU country and you’re bringing a vehicle with you on a temporary visit to the UK

In all other cases, you must pay VAT on the vehicle, any accessories bought with the vehicle and any delivery or incidental charges. 

You can do this at customs, or by using the forms below to tell HMRC.

## Telling HMRC

You must usually tell HMRC when importing a vehicle. The only exception is if you normally live in another EU country and are bringing a vehicle with you on a temporary visit to the UK. 

If you have to tell HMRC, you must do this within 7 days of when the vehicle arrived in the UK or when you bought the vehicle (whichever is later). Otherwise, you may have to pay a fine.

Tell HMRC using 1 of the following forms:

- [VAT 415](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageVAT_Forms&propertyType=document&id=HMCE_CL_000059 "Form VAT 415"){:rel="external"} - if you’re an individual personally importing a New Means of Transport (NMT)
- [VAT 414](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageVAT_Forms&propertyType=document&id=HMCE_CL_000051 "Form VAT 414"){:rel="external"} - if your vehicle isn't an NMT or you’re a VAT-registered trader bringing in commercial imports
- BFG 414 - for customs relieved vehicles personally acquired by British Forces Germany personnel (see [HMRC's advice on NMTs, part 4](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageLibrary_ShowContent&propertyType=document&id=HMCE_CL_000165 "New Means of Transport: HMRC"){:rel="external"}

When you send in form VAT 415 or 414, HMRC will send you back form VAT 413. If you haven't already paid any tax and duty due, you’ll need to send this form back to HMRC with the correct amount.

## Vehicle tax
You’ll have to pay [vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-rate-tables "Vehicle tax rate tables") from the date your vehicle is first registered in the UK.

## Further advice and information

You can get more information by [contacting HMRC](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?cs=UTF-8&ha=34&tx0=67&fl0=contactid:&raction=view "Contact HMRC"){:rel="external"} or on their website:

- [Importing returned goods free of duty and tax](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageImport_ShowContent&id=HMCE_CL_000226&propertyType=document "Importing returned goods free of duty and tax"){:rel="external"}
- [Importing inherited goods free of duty and VAT](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageImport_ShowContent&id=HMCE_CL_000065&propertyType=document “Importing inherited goods free of duty and VAT”){:rel="external"}

*[NMT]: New Means of Transport
*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Custom
*[EU]: European Union
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[HM]: Her Majesty's
*[VAT]: Value Added Tax
table.title: VAT, duty and tax: vehicles from within the EU

table.body:
If your vehicle is imported from outside the [European Union (EU),](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "Countries in the EU: Europa"){:rel="external"} you may qualify for certain types of relief, meaning you don’t have to pay VAT or duty.

###Transfer of residence relief
You won't have to pay duty or VAT on the vehicle if you meet all these conditions:

- you're moving your normal home to the UK
- you’ve had your normal home outside the EU for a continuous period of at least 12 months
- you’ve owned and used the vehicle for at least 6 months outside the EU
- you didn't get the vehicle under a duty/tax-free scheme
- you're going to keep the vehicle for your personal use for at least 12 months after it's imported

To claim the relief, fill in [form C104A](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/forms/view.page?record=cwjlXbaGs7Q&formid=98 "Form C104A"){:rel="external"} and present it when you bring the vehicle into the country.

###Returned goods relief 
You won’t have to pay duty or VAT if you’re re-importing a vehicle that was previously exported out of the EU, provided you meet all these conditions:

- the vehicle was taken outside the EU by you within the past 3 years
- any VAT, duty or equivalent tax was paid on the vehicle in the EU and wasn’t refunded when the vehicle was taken outside the EU
- the vehicle hasn’t been altered outside the EU, other than necessary running repairs

To claim the relief, drive your vehicle through the ‘green channel’. You must be able to show evidence that:

- the vehicle was exported
- you were the person who exported it

###Temporary admission relief
You won’t have to pay duty or VAT if you’re a non-EU resident and your vehicle is registered or belongs to a non-EU resident.

You must also:

- be bringing the vehicle into the UK temporarily for your own private use
- re-export it from the EU within 6 months - this time limit can be extended if you’re a student or undertaking an assignment of a specific duration 
- not sell, lend or hire it out anywhere in the EU

You don’t need to notify HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to claim the relief. However, completing [form C110](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/forms/view.page?record=i-925dmh8yY&formId=111 “Form C110: Notice of arrival of a private motor vehicle”){:rel="external"} can help customs identify you and might stop the vehicle being unnecessarily detained if the police carry out checks.

### Paying VAT or duty

If you don’t qualify for a relief, you’ll have to pay VAT or duty by filling in:

- form C&E 386 - if you’re an individual personally importing a vehicle 
- [form C&E 389](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/forms/view.page?record=lty64uaaaqo&formId=256 "Form C&E 389"){:rel="external"} - if you’re a VAT-registered trader bringing in commercial imports

You can request form C&E 386 from [HMRC's excise and customs helpline.](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49682&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view "Contact HMRC's excise and customs helpline"){:rel="external"}

When HMRC is satisfied that you, or the shipping agent, have paid duty and VAT (if applicable), it will issue you with a form that lets you register the vehicle with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

## Vehicle tax
You’ll have to pay [vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-rate-tables "Vehicle tax rate tables") from the date your vehicle is first registered in the UK.

## Further advice and information

You can get more information by [contacting HMRC](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?cs=UTF-8&ha=34&tx0=67&fl0=contactid:&raction=view "Contact HMRC"){:rel="external"} or on their website:

- [Bringing your vehicle to the UK from outside the EU](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageTravel_ShowContent&id=HMCE_CL_000282&propertyType=document "Bringing your vehicle to the UK from outside the EU"){:rel="external"}
- [Importing returned goods free of duty and tax](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageImport_ShowContent&id=HMCE_CL_000226&propertyType=document "Importing returned goods free of duty and tax"){:rel="external"}
- [Importing inherited goods free of duty and VAT](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageImport_ShowContent&id=HMCE_CL_000065&propertyType=document “Importing inherited goods free of duty and VAT”){:rel="external"}

*[NMT]: New Means of Transport
*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Custom
*[EU]: European Union
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[HM]: Her Majesty's
*[VAT]: Value Added Tax
table.title: VAT, duty and tax: vehicles from outside the EU

table.body:
If you're importing a vehicle into the UK permanently, you'll need to register it.

You must follow all the instructions for [registering a new vehicle](/vehicle-registration/new-registrations "New registrations"). In addition, you’ll need to include with your application:

- evidence of [type approval or certificate of Mutual Recognition](/importing-vehicles-into-the-uk/mutual-recognition-and-type-approval "Mutual Recognition and type approval")
- if the vehicle is new, form V267 (‘Declaration that a vehicle is new’)
- foreign registration documents or any papers relating to the vehicle
- evidence showing the date the vehicle was collected (normally the invoice from the supplier)
- the appropriate HM Revenue and Customs forms, showing you've paid [VAT and/or duty](/importing-vehicles-into-the-uk/vat-duty-and-tax-vehicles-from-within-the-eu "VAT, duty and tax: vehicles from within the EU") (if applicable)

$D
[Download form V267 'Declaration that a vehicle is new' (PDF, 158KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/documents/digitalasset/dg_4009589.pdf "Download form V267 'Declaration that a vehicle is new' (PDF, 158KB)"){:rel="external"} 
$D

You’ll need to use original documents - you can't use photocopies or faxed copies.

In some cases, the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) local office may want to see the vehicle to check its identity.

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Registering an imported vehicle

table.body:
You can drive a vehicle to Britain and register it as 'new' if all the following apply:

- it’s registered within 2 weeks of collection (extended to 1 calendar month at peak periods, eg before 1 March and 1 September)
- it hasn’t been previously permanently registered
- it's been stored before registration and is a current model or a model that’s stopped being made within the last 2 years

^The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) advises you to transport rather than drive your vehicle from the port to its first destination.^
table.title: Registering a vehicle as 'new'

table.body:
You can usually use a vehicle displaying non-UK number plates, and not have to tax or register it in the UK, if:

- you're visiting the UK and don’t plan to live here
- you only use the vehicle up to 6 months in a 12-month period (1 single visit, or several shorter visits adding up to a 6-month period)
- the vehicle is registered and taxed in its home country

%If you become a resident in the UK, you must tax and register your vehicle in the UK straight away.%

## Customs relief for non-EU vehicles

You may be able to claim relief from customs charges if your vehicle is registered outside the European Union (EU) and you're bringing it to the UK temporarily. 

You can do this by using [form C110 - temporary admission.](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/forms/view.page?formid=111&record=i-925dmh8yY "C110 - temporary admission"){:rel="external"}

You can find more information, and the conditions you need to meet, in ['Temporary admission - temporarily importing non-EU means of transport'.](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageLibrary_ShowContent&id=HMCE_CL_000237&propertyType=document "Temporary admission - temporarily importing non-EU means of transport"){:rel="external"}

If you meet the conditions, you can take your vehicle through the ‘nothing to declare’ channel when you arrive in the UK.

If HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) tells you that your vehicle needs to be registered and taxed in the UK, you must fill in form C&E 388. You can get this from the National Import Relief Unit (NIRU).

$A
NIRU  
Abbey House  
Head Street  
Enniskillen  
Country Fermanagh  
BT 74 7JL
$A

## Students and workers

You may be able to use a vehicle with non-UK number plates for longer than a 6-month period, without taxing or registering it, if all the following apply:

- you're a student or worker
- you normally live outside the UK
- you're in the UK for a set study or work period
- the vehicle is registered in its home country

%You must contact HMRC before or upon arrival in the UK to apply for customs relief.%

If you meet the conditions above, HMRC will give you a customs relief form which you can present to the police if you're stopped when driving your vehicle.

If your vehicle is eligible for customs relief and you stay in the UK after it expires (normally at the end of the study or work period), you must [register and tax your vehicle](registering-an-imported-vehicle "Registering an imported vehicle") in the UK.

## When you need 'Q' number plates

You must get temporary 'Q' number plates if you visit the UK for up to 6 months and either of the following apply:

- your number plates display numbers and/or letters that aren't identifiable in the UK (eg Arabic script)
- your vehicle isn't registered in its home country

You'll need to fill in [certain forms and follow certain rules.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Motoring/BuyingAndSellingAVehicle/ImportingAndExportingAVehicle/DG_197428 "Getting a Q number plate during a short visit to the UK"){:rel="external"} 

## If you're stopped by the police

If your car has non-UK number plates and you're stopped by police, you must show you can use the vehicle in the UK without taxing and registering it here. 

You may have to show proof of the length of time you've been in the UK (eg a ferry ticket) or evidence that you and the vehicle are eligible for customs relief.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[HM]: Her Majesty's
*[EU]: European Union
*[NIRU]: National Import Relief Unit
table.title: Temporary imports

table.body:
If your vehicle is registered in Great Britain (GB) or Northern Ireland (NI), you can move it freely between the two. It won't count as an import. 

You can keep your original registration number, number plates and tax disc. Alternatively, you can ask for a new registration number. 

To apply for a GB registration number:

- use the vehicle registration certificate Northern Ireland (V5CNI)
- apply at a [DVLA local office](http://www.dft.gov.uk/dvla/contactus/localoffices/findnear.aspx "Find your DVLA local office"){:rel="external"}

To apply for an NI registration number:

- use the vehicle registration certificate (V5C) 
- apply at the [Driver and Vehicle Agency (DVA)](http://www.dvtani.gov.uk/home/contactus.asp "Contact DVA"){:rel="external"}

*[GB]: Great Britain
*[NI]: Northern Ireland
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[DVA]: Driver and Vehicle Agency
table.title: Moving vehicles between Britain and Northern Ireland
